description.narrative: -Existence of 10 fully functional regional peace councils in accordance with its Act -Number of conflict assessment studies commissioned and completed -draft NPC 5 year strategic plan (2012-2016) in place -Conduct 9 trainings for NPC Board, staff and police in quantitative and qualitative analysis, dialogue, mediation and negotiation skills, conflict management, tolerance -improved technical and operational capacity of NPC Number of studies produced providing information on the role of civil society in conflict mitigation -Number of women and youth trained and involved in electoral violence prevention -draft baseline report on SALW situation in Ghana Prepared

comment.narrative: -New NPC in place and 7 out of 10 regions RPCs functional -Conflict prevention initiatives are not guided by scientific background studies -NPC has no 5 year strategic plan (2012-2016) -Limited knowledge and skills of new NPC Board and staff, and the police in quantitative and qualitative analysis, dialogue, mediation and negotiation skills, conflict management, tolerance, trust, confidence building -NPC ACT (818) in place but staff need capacity support -No comprehensive baseline document on the role of civil society stakeholders in conflict mitigation -Limited capacity and involvement of women and youth in conflict prevention -inadequate, out dated data on small arms proliferation -Limited involvement of CSOs, women and youth in conflict prevention and mediation processes

1) The NPC/RPCs intervenes in at least 2 new conflicts in addition to the previous 6 conflicts by end of 2016 2) Train 30 traditional/religious leaders to intervene in at least two conflicts by end of 2016. 3) Capacity of at least 50 peace actors built (50% women) to intervene in election related violence, in 2015 and 2016. 3) SALW baseline survey published. 4) Women/youth intervene in at least 2 new conflicts by the end of 2016.

The NPC through its Regional Peace Councils intervened in more than 2 emerging conflicts. For instance the Brong Ahafo Regional Peace Council intervened in the Tuobodom and Kwapong conflicts, leading to relative peace and paving way for dialogue between the factions. Similarly, the intervention of the Upper East Regional Peace Council led to the reconstitution of the Bawku Inter-Ethnic Peace Committee, which brought the parties together, to find a lasting resolution to the conflict, rather than an externally imposed solution. The NPC also intervened in some ongoing conflicts in Hohoe and Alavanyo-Akonya. Though the training has not commenced, a significant milestone in this regard is the development of the training manuals, a primary tool for the training. The NPC with the support of the UNDP and the EU organized dialogue sessions with Governance Institutions (Electoral Commission, the Security Agencies, and the National Commission for Civic Education among others), the Media and Civil Society Organizations (CSOs). The sessions reviewed the work of these institutions in the 2012 election, highlighting the best and not so good practices with a view to strategizing for election 2016. The respective institutions enhanced their knowledge on what they can do to ensure a credible and peaceful 2016 election. Though the SAWL has not been published, a major step is the validation and proofreading of the report, therefore making it ready for publication in the ensuing year. The capacity of over 30 women and youth were built in peacebuilding and mediation to enable them intervene in at least 2 emerging conflicts in 2016.

1) The NPC/RPCs intervenes in at least 2 emerging conflicts in addition to the previous 8 conflicts by end of 2016. 2)Train at least 30 traditional/religious leaders to intervene in at least two conflicts by end of 2016. 3) Early Warning System developed and operationalised. 4)SALW baseline survey published and some recommendations implemented. 5)Women/youth intervene in at least 2 new conflicts by the end of 2016. 6) Capacity of at least 50 peace actors built (50% women) to intervene in election related violence, in 2015 and 2016 7) 10% improved levels of voter knowledge on peace building and conflict prevention as of 2017 first quarter

With UNDP’s support, the National Peace Council(NPC) was able to intervene in three conflicts in Tafo, Asunafo North, South and Sankore. The Tafo conflict was a land dispute, while the other was an electoral dispute. There is ongoing intervention efforts in other ongoing conflicts like Bimbilla, Bawku, Alavanyo etc.
25 Chiefs and Queen Mothers alongside 5 officers of the Western Regional House of Chiefs have been trained in mediation.
The Governing Board of the NPC and RPCs capacity has been strengthened in early warning and response mechanisms with the setting NEEWARG AND THE REEWARGS.UNDP in collaboration with CIDA (Canada), DANIDA (Denmark) procured 10 vehicles for the National and Regional Peace Councils to aid in Early Response
Second Small Arms and Light Weapons Baseline Survey completed and published in 2016 and over 1300 weapons collected from armories destroyed on international small Arms day. Engagement with political party chairmen and general secretaries led to the signing of a communique that committed them to dissociate themselves from vigilante groups, not employ the services of militant pressure groups at any time during and after the election and denounce and renounce violence in solving electoral disputes
The Women’s Situation Room (WSR) an initiative aimed at promoting peace during and after the elections played a huge role in galvanizing women to work for peace during the 2016 elections
The training session for the 130 members of the Regional and National Peace Councils was conducted to enable them intervene in election related violence. Dialogue sessions with Governance institutions, media and CSOs to review their roles in the 2012 election whilst strategizing for the 2016 election have also been organized.349 media practitioners have also been engaged on their role in peace messaging
3,131 individuals received civic, voter as well as peace education. Out of this number 1,102 were female of which 80 of these females were people with

1). The NPC/RPCs intervenes in at least 2 emerging conflicts in addition to the previous 10 conflicts by end of 2017. 2). Early Warning System developed and operationalized. 3). At least three (3) studies/research published and one study conducted. 4). Database to monitor the use of SALW operational. 5). Women/youth intervene in at least 2 new conflicts by the end of 2016.

1). With support from UNDP and DANIDA, NPC/RPC intervened in the Bimbilla Conflict, bringing together the parties to the conflict, citizens leaving outside the conflict zone, Civil Society and Media to chart a path to peace. As a result of this intervention, the feuding parties have formed a joint committee, that meet periodically to deliberate on how to attain peace. Similarly, as a result of this intervention, a media House in Bimbilla has allocated airtime to the NPC every Friday to educate the people on the need for peaceful co-existence. Again, there is now a structured intervention approach jointly adopted by the NPC and CSOs on how to mediate in the conflict following from the engagement.
2). Four (4) studies of the NPC, a). Capacity Needs Assessment of Ghana's Peace Architecture at the National, Regional and District Level. b). Communication Strategy, c). Mapping Conflict in Ghana and d). Baseline Report on The Role of Civil Society in Conflict Prevention, Particularly the Level of Participation of Women and the Youth) have all been published and disseminated.
3). The Capacity of sixty (60) women and youth from six conflict affected areas enhanced. This followed two separate training conducted in the Southern and Northern sectors to capacitate youth and women from conflict affected areas in order for them to intervene appropriately in these conflicts.
4) Forty-Eight (48) Members of the National Board of the National Peace Council and Regional Peace Councils including Twelve (12) females participated in a five days’ teambuilding and stocktaking exercise with the aim of building a stronger, sustainable and resilient council that will be able interact with itself as well as chart a common path in dealing with the changing dynamics of conflicts and threats to peace and security in Ghana. Communication between the National Peace Council and their Regional offices have improved greatly after this exercise.

-Local Government Service Secretariat produce monitoring report on decentralisation process -Local administrative staff trained in decentralisation process -debates organised on constitutional reforms -knowledge products on the code and NMC monitoring function produced and distributed -citizens more aware of about policy options in electoral agendas -increased capacity of EC staff, media and citizen to work together -increase in the rate of women and the vulnerable activity working toward reaching leadership and decision-making positions

comment.narrative: -Tracing mechanisms to assess decentralisation progress are weak -lack of awareness about decentralisation process among local administrative staff -limited public discussions and awareness of CRC recommendations -Breaches of the media code of conduct -Citizens not well informed about electoral agendas -need for more civic education content in the curriculum -level of public confidence in the administration of elections -low representation of women and vulnerable groups in decision making and leadership positions

1) 40% (NB target will be appropriately adjusted when baseline is determined by GAP Poll ) of voter population have some knowledge in the proposed constitutional amendments recommended by the Constitution Review Report by 2016 (source GAP Poll 2016) 2) 60% of citizens trust the Electoral Commission to deliver on its mandate by the end of 2016 3) National policy on Popular Participation in Local Governance 100% developed and validated by end-2016 4) A Baseline of 76% of citizens who had not contacted any district assembly official in the past 12 months to discuss an important issue by the end of 2014 reduces to 70% by end-2016 5) total of 25,000 citizens participating in nationwide governance assessments by end of 2016 6) Six (6) initiatives established and/or supported to promote women’s participation in decision-making processes by 2016 7): Developed baseline on HIV related stigma and discrimination by 2016

The planned activities for the constitutional review could not be implemented as a result of a court injunction that was placed on the process since the last quarter of 2014. The case was determined and dismissed in the October 2015. The Committee has been meeting to plan public sensitization and a referendum. The Electoral Commission (EC) experienced a number of material changes in 2015 creating uncertainty and causing the trust of citizens in the Commission to decrease to 40% (Gap Poll 2015). The most significant change was the retirement of the EC Chairman who had been at the helm for 23 years. There were some public protests prior to the appointment which was finally made midyear. The new Chair who is external to the EC does not have any elections experience at the time of the appointment but is supported by two deputies who although have been with the EC longer are still relatively new to election management. Additionally the EC’s image has suffered somehow from many challenges in the aftermath of the 2008 and 2012 presidential elections. The Supreme Court in 2013 and subsequently a reform committee as well as the Inter-party Advisory Committee (IPAC) enumerated over 20 reforms for the institution. Finally the credibility of the Voters Register (VR) in its current state is in doubt. The leading opposition party in Ghana, the NPP has formerly requested for a new register for the 2016 elections on the basis that it is incurably flawed. This claim is resisted by the governing NDC. The EC has endorsed the recommendation to clean the current register by an eminent panel who investigated the positions and evidence presented by all political parties, civil society organizations and citizens in a public forum and its ensuing consultations. The EC recognizing the critical need to reposition the institution and further enhance its credibility, sought support from UNDP. 1) 40% (NB target will be appropriately adjusted when baseline is determined by GAP Poll ) of voter population have some knowledge in the proposed constitutional amendments recommended by the Constitution Review Report by 2016 (source GAP Poll 2016) 2) 60% of citizens trust the Electoral Commission to deliver on its mandate by the end of 2016 3) National policy on Popular Participation in Local Governance implemented in 50% of MMDAs in Ghana 4) A Baseline of 76% of citizens who had not contacted any district assembly official in the past 12 months to discuss an important issue by the end of 2014 reduces to 70% by end-2016 5) total of 25,000 citizens participating in nationwide governance assessments by end of 2016 6) Six (6) initiatives established and/or supported to promote women’s participation in decision-making processes by 2016 7) Developed a national HIV Anti Stigma Strategy

Despite the fact that the court suit against the constitutional review process was dismissed in October 2015 and the Constitutional review implementation committee's mandate renewed until December 2016, uncertainty about introducing the bills for parliament and a referendum resulted in planned activities not being implemented. Even though the implementation committee held a series of meetings with the Electoral Commission, political parties and government to build consensus ,interests of the 2016 general elections overwhelmed stakeholder will and commitment needed to successfully conduct the referendum and introduce the bills to parliament
UNDP provided technical support to the Electoral Commission to conduct an analysis of the voter’s register, engaged stakeholders; especially political parties consistently to enable them prepare efficiently for the 2016 elections. In addition, UNDP provided financial support to procure 285 projectors and screens, to enable Ghanaians in all the 275 Constituency Collation Centres (CCC), 10 regional offices and the National Collation Centre view the collation of the results; this ensured public confidence and trust in the 2016 elections results
Policy Framework and Practitioner Manual has been validated and now going to print.Technocrats, civil society organizations, PWDs, women, youth at both the National and Subnational levels participated in regional validation workshops.
13,747 citizens (42.3% females) participated in the nationwide Governance assessment (APRM, District governance assessment report)Interface accountability platforms enhanced rapport between citizens and MMDAs in addressing concerns raised by LANets in 8 districts. A total of 192 participants were reached including 158 males and 34 females,(GACC report).UNDP supported the local governance network (LOGNET) to conduct assessments to determine the extent to which persons with disabilities engaged with the local government. 1) 40% of voter population have some knowledge in the proposed constitutional amendments recommended by the Constitution Review Report by 2017 (Source: GaP Poll 2017) 2) Implement National Framework on popular participation in 50% of MMDA’s Ghana 3) A Baseline of 76% of citizens who had not contacted any district assembly official in the past 12 months to discuss an important issue reduced to 70% by end-2017 4) A total of 25,000 citizens participating in nationwide governance assessments by end of 2017 5) Six (6) initiatives established and/or supported to promote women’s participation in decision-making processes by 2017 6) 100 PLHIVs reached with key provisions of the GAC Act

UNDP supported the IMCC to implement a training activity for over 50 personnel of MMDAs in the Volta Region, on the National Framework on Popular Participation Practitioners’ Manual.The National Popular Framework has the sole purpose of institutionalizing popular participation as part of the fabric of Ghana’s public administration architecture. Popular participation seeks to promote local democracy, participation and accountability through strong and viable stakeholder involvement. The training improved and strengthened the skills and knowledge of the attendees, on engendering grass root participation in policy formulation as well as development of strategies that focus on accountability. MMDAs in the Volta Region are utilizing the National Framework on Popular Participation 80 persons with disabilities (PWDs) have been enlightened on the provisions of the new local governance act . Equipped with the provisions of the new local governance Act, PWDs can explore and identify opportunities for engaging with the local district assembly.Youth and disability friendly animation videos have been developed to highlight the avenues for youth engagement as mandated by the national youth authority Act. Over 100 young people between the ages of 15-35 from youth organizations and disability associations from all over Ghana have been reached with the key provisions of the National Youth Authority Act. Armed with these provisions young people can effectively engage at the local level.Accountability between citizens and MMDAs enhanced through the interface platforms in 8 districts- 4 districts in Volta region,3 central region and 1 in Greater Accra region District governance assessment reports for 2015 has been finalized and ready for printing and dissemination in the second half of the year. 1) Strengthen data management and policy for capacities to ensure appropriate national indicators for monitoring the SDGs. 2) Finalize National Infrastructure Plan by December 2016. 3) 2018-2021 Planning Guidelines with Long Term Development Plan and SDGs indicators integrated prepared by December 2016. 4) South-South cooperation and peer to peer learning enhanced and technical support for National Development Planning Commission. 5) SDGs dashboard established and integrated into the one-stop shop. 6) Development Cooperation Policy Launched by June 2016. 7) Access to improved sanitation for market women in 3 major markets 8) Youth advocacy for SDGs. 9) At least 2 analytical work to inform policy and development planning. 10) Coordinated Approach to National Development Underpinned by Mining. 11) Real time monitoring system for tracking State of the Nation Address (SONA) in place by 2016.

In line with the UNDAF and UNDP Ghana outcomes, the 2016 Promoting Inclusive Growth and Development Annual Work Plan aimed at enhancing the capacity of Ministries, Department and Agencies (MDAs), Local Governments and CSOs to effectively develop, coordinate and implement national and sectoral policies, plans and programmes targeted at reducing poverty and inequalities as well as promoting inclusive socio-economic growth. Specifically, the following are expected from the implementation of the AWP: *Enhanced capacities for data management and analytical work to inform policy and planning aimed at promoting inclusive socio-economic growth; * Inequality and promotion of structural transformation improved; *Institutional development and transformation for inclusive and sustainable growth *Increased development dialogues and South-South Exchanges Results from actions taken to realize the outcomes stated above are: 1) Supported the identification and formulation of indicators for the localization of the SDGs to ensure the collection of standard administrative data for the monitoring of the SDGs; and partnerships further strengthened among data collection government agencies to enhance data harmonization and usefulness.
2) Provided technical and financial support for the development of the National Infrastructure Plan as a component of the 40-year Long Term Development Plan. In addition, UNDP provided technical assistance for the formulation and development of the Long Term National Development Plan. 3) To ensure the embedment of the SDGs in the next planning cycle, UNDP provided technical and financial support to the development of Planning and ME guidelines for the preparation of the next sectoral and local 2018-2021 Medium Term Development frameworks. 4) UNDP facilitated two south-south arrangements between Governments of Ghana (GoG) and Namibia; and between GoG and South Korea. 1) Public service integrity programme operational 2) Review and adopt at least one anti-corruption legislation 3) Baseline reduced to 80% 4) 80 MDAs and MMDAs have published Client Charters by 2015 5) 460 cases reported and 400 resolved 6) At least one criminal justice institution operating a functional case management system 7) Baseline reduces to 60%

In 2015, National Anti-Corruption Action Plan (NACAP) implementation began with the finalization of a monitoring and evaluation framework to track progress. A public integrity programme was launched with designated Ethics officers from 35 Ministries, Departments and Agencies (MDAs) fully aware of their role in championing public sector ethics and integrity. Over 100 investigators of the Commission for Human Rights and Administrative Justice have improved capacity to investigate breaches of the code of conduct for public officers (President’s address at NACAP Conference; CHRAJ annual report) To implement UNCAC Ghana review report recommendation, two anti-corruption bills (Witness Protection bill, Conduct of Public Officers’ Bill) have been drafted while an existing legislation (whistle Blower Act) is being amended, the Conduct of Public Officers’ Bill and the whistle Blower Act Amendment bill are both at the consideration stage in Parliament, the Witness Protection bill is gone for cabinet approval. These were done through consultations with Parliamentarians, public servants and CSOs. (MoJAGD annual report; CHRAJ annual Report). As a result of the findings of the anti-Corruption baseline survey on the Customs, an integrity Manual and curriculum has been developed for staff training. Lessons learnt on the implementation of Client service charters in the past has been documented through a baseline survey conducted. The findings of this survey will guide the development of a prototype client service chapter for adoption and implementation by all public institutions for improved service delivery Speedy and efficient delivery of administrative justice cases achieved; 196 cases resolved of 236 cases received in 2015. This was possible due to the capacity building of CHRAJ staff on the effective and efficient handling of cases. In order to address comprehensively some of the key findings of the 2012 baseline such as lack of communication and coordination among the just

Anti corruption measures in the Public sector were strengthened with the development of Integrity compliance tools such as Code of Compliance Survey Questionnaire, Gift Policy and Statement Gift Register by the National Ethics Advisory Committee with UNDP’s support. Further, the National Anti Corruption Action Plan's (NACAP) Monitoring and Evaluation Annual Work Plan and M E Tool were also developed in 2016 ( NACAP 2016, Annual report). Ghana's participation in the UNCAC Implementation Review Group Meeting in Vienna was supported in preparation for the review of Indonesia by Ghana and Yemen. An average of 266 persons per week have been reached with Anti-Corruption information on Twitter and Facebook platforms (GACC report) 25 staff of the Customs Division of GRA equipped to promote integrity in their service as a result of knowledge gained through a UNDP supported training of trainer’s workshop using the Ethics and Anti-Corruption Manual developed in 2015 Trainee’s Manual, Trainer’s Manual, Training Curriculum and Training Plan have also been developed and printed for the customs division of the GRA. Integrity Hotlines have also been introduced and are active Report on Study of implementation of Client Charters in Ghana have been validated by stakeholders. The Framework for the development of Prototype Client Charter have also been developed and validated. Ex post evaluation of the ombudsman training has also commenced With UNDP support, the Legal and Justice Sector institutions are equipped to work in a more transparent, standardize manner and provide specialized, structured training to their staff with the finalization and validation of Standard Operating Procedures(SOPs) for Criminal Justice Institutions, Training Plan for MoJAGD and Agencies and other Criminal Justice Institutions and Change Management Strategy. comment.narrative: Ghana has been recommended for inclusion in the second phase of the UNDP Low Emission Capacity Building Programme. The LECBP is one of the flagship programme implemented by UNDP to support countries to develop low emission, climate resilient development strategies.

1) 2 energy related Nationally Appropriate Mitigation Actions (NAMAs) developed 2) Ghana's Intended Nationally Determined Contribution (INDC) submitted to UNFCCC 3) NAMAs Investor Guide promoted among the business community 4) Operational Manual for Greenhouse Gas Inventory prepared

1) A Nationally Appropriate Mitigation Action (NAMA) in the energy sector was developed, in order to trigger climate finance. Two different NAMAs concepts (one on the establishment of market-based cleaner cooking solutions and one on incorporation of renewable systems into households and commercial activities) were merged into one broader NAMA that could be more attractive for potential funders.)
2) The focus of the project for this year has been on the development of Ghana’s Intended Nationally Determined Contribution (INDC) to UNFCCC, in view of the 21st Conference of Parties of UNFCCC that met in Paris to agree on a new global climate change agreement. The INDC was developed through the establishment of two national technical working groups (one for mitigation, one for adaptation) that relied on strong national expertise from public sector, academia and civil society. The draft document underwent stakeholder and political consultations, and the final document submitted to UNFCCC before the deadline. In summary, Ghana is committing to reduce carbon emissions by 15% by 2030 compared to business as usual scenario unconditionally (with national resources), and an additional 30% conditionally (with external support). The INDC includes adaptation goals and a MRV system. The quality of the document was rated as good by UNDP HQ. The project also supported the preparations of the delegation to COP21, as well as the organization of a side event (Ghana Day), to showcase Ghana’s progress in putting in place a policy framework to address climate change.
3) The NAMA Investor Guide was finalized and published. However, no promotion activities have been undertaken by the Ghana Investment Promotion Centre and they have been slated to 2016.
4) In order to strengthen Greenhouse Gases Inventory Systems, two important documents have been developed: QA/QC Plan and Guidance on Uncertainty Management for National Greenhouse Gas Inventory; National Greenhouse Gas Inventory Manual o

1)Up to 2 financed energy-related NAMAs formulated in context of national development priorities, including associated MRV system 2) NAMAs Investor Guide promoted among the business community 3) National system for preparation of GHG inventories strengthened

1) Up to 2 financeable energy-related NAMAs formulated in context of national development priorities, including associated MRV system The NAMA(s) for RE and cooking solutions has been completed. Ghana’s National Designated Authority for the Green Climate Fund (Ministry of Finance) nominated UNDP as Multilateral Implementing Entity for the NAMA developed by LECB last year. Consultations have started to discuss the way forward, in collaboration with the UNDP/UNEP Green Climate Fund Readiness Programme.
2) Ghana NAMAs Investor Guide reviewed and promoted among the business community An MOU was signed between the IP and the Private Enterprise Federation to implement the NAMA Investor Guide related activities. PEF organized two sensitization workshops aimed at raising awareness about existing investment opportunities in climate change mitigation as outlined in the Ghana NAMA Investor Guide. The NAMA Private Sector Platform was established with members from the NAMA sectors (energy, waste, agriculture, forestry, transport and industries). The aim of the platform is to create an enabling environment for dialogue and partnerships with government and multilateral agencies for NAMA implementation.
3) National system for preparation of GHG inventories strengthened In collaboration with the GCF Readiness Programme in Ghana, the establishment of National MRV Systems for Climate Action and Climate Support/Finance were initiated to further enhance ghg inventory and reporting via the Ghana Climate Change Data Hub. The MRV System for Climate Action focused on the design of a climate data template and a set of workable indicators to collate detailed information on 42 climate change actions. The climate data template has been validated and will now be used to collate data on climate projects in the country. The development of a detailed common MRV programme for continuous greenhouse gas data collection, estimation and reporting for the electricity sub-sector was completed. A train

comment.narrative: Ghana ratified the Montreal Protocol on 24 July 1989. In 1991, it established the National Ozone Office within the Environmental Protection Agency to respond to mandates of the amended Montreal Protocol. The Executive Committee of the Multilateral Fund approved the Ghana Country Programme for the Phase out of Ozone Depleting Substances according to the Montreal Protocol at the Eighth Meeting of the Executive Committee of the Interim Multilateral Fund for the Implementation of the Montreal Protocol in October 1992. Since then, the National Ozone Unit has received support (in phases) from the Multilateral Fund through UNDP to meet national targets in reduction of CFCs and HCFCs (for HCFCs: 10% reduction by 2015 and 35% reduction by 2020)

1) Ensure Ghana's compliance with Article 7 and 9 of the Montreal Protocol by: - Reduction in ODS consumption and refrigerant end-users protected from the use of sub-standard refrigerants. This activity will also ensure compliance of Ghana's consumption of controlled ODS - To enable government make informed decisions and take appropriate policy actions - Reduction of ODS Consumption during servicing 2) Increased knowledge on the need to protect the Ozone Layer and related issues

1) In order to achieve target 1, a data collection exercise was conducted to assess national consumption of CFC for the year 2014. A report which detailed out a total of approximately 358,809.40 volumes of refrigerants ( R22,R 134a,R 406,R 407,R 5007 etc) collected was sent to the Montreal protocol secretariat in compliance with Article 7 and 9 for Ghana on the Montreal Protocol. Seemingly a survey was conducted to identify the different brands of refrigerant on the Ghanaian market whose outcome depicted the influx of mislabelled /adulterated and fake refrigerant on the Ghanaian market. Hence the need to put in place measures to address the capacity needs of the customs officials at the various borders/posts or entry points of the country. 2) A total of 881 students (500males and 331 females) participated in the awareness creation activity which aimed at increasing the knowledge of the young generation on the need to protect the Ozone layer.

1. Collect data on ODS to assess national consumption of CFC for 2015 2. Conduct monitoring to identify the brands of refrigerants on the Ghanaian market 3. Monitor converted AC units to ensure that they remain safe and intact and also ensure compliance to the controls for hydrocarbon use 4. Create awareness on ODS

1. In order to comply with Ghana’s reporting requirements to the Montreal Protocol, the project collected data of ODS to assess national consumption of CFC for the year 2015. Volumes collected included R22 -139,058.00 Kg; R134a - 107,566.00 Kg; R406 - 106,149.60 Kg; R407 - 47,136.00 Kg; R404 -32,574.00 Kg; R410 - 10,623.00 Kg; R600 – 4,540.00 Kg; R507 – 4,254.00 Kg. 2. Monitoring was conducted in 5 regions, 10 towns and 73 outlets, to identify the different brands of refrigerants in the Ghanaian market. This allowed the Environmental Protection Agency to identify fake, mislabeled, and adulterated refrigerants, which were confiscated as follows: Identified fake/mislabeled/adulterated and confiscated refrigerants included: R 12 – 16.6 Kg; R409 – 26 Kg; R407 – 75 Kg; R134a – 82.6 kg. Refrigerant Random Test Results: Good - 55%; Mislabelled - 34% (R409); Bad - 3%; Unknown - 8%. Status of outlets Registered with the EPA: Registered – 79%; Unregistered – 21%. Arrangement of Refrigerants in outlets: Good – 10%; Satisfactory – 29%; Bad – 61% 3. A total of four (4) regions, Thirteen (13) towns and ninety five (95) outlets were visited. The number of AC units tested were 984 and all the units were still running on HC R 290. The results suggests that the conversion is doing well and there were no reported incidence of fire indicating that the trained technicians were up to the task given to them. 4. Awareness creation. A seminar was held for second cycle institutions on ODS in the Ashanti Region of Ghana. This awareness raising on ODS using educational institutions is a major instrument of change and development. 433 students (Male -307; Female- 126) were educated on the causes and effects of ozone depletion, remediate actions, sustainable lifestyles to help reduce the phenomenon and save the ozone layer. More than five hundred (500) students and staff participated in the celebration of the International Day for the Preservation of the Ozone Layer for 2nd cycle schools o
No target (project completed)

1. Exit strategy for the CREW Project is being developed. 2. UNDP supported the full operationalization of the flood and drought Early Warning System (EWS). Through this support, NADMO completed the testing of an effective flood and drought Early Warning system at the NADMO HQ, 10 Regional Offices and in 10 districts across the Country. The Community Resilience through Early Warning system (CREW EWS) uses open free of charge satellite based meteorological data and provides a basic flood and drought forecast for all the pilot areas. The CREW EWS exists of two systems: an expert system that collects data, calculates forecasts and presents all relevant data and a web dissemination tool called “Dashboard” that visualizes specific warnings and flood hazard information through a dedicated website. With the aid of these systems, the skill in estimates of the intensity of rainfall is expected to improve to provide reasonably accurate rainfall forecasts to issue early warning. Institutions like the National Disaster Management Organization (NADMO) and the pilot districts need warning information about abnormally high or untimely rainfall to enable them to mobilize in advance. In the coming years, it is expected that the EWS will help make contingency planning and evacuation more precise and therefore, put people and potentially economic/livelihood assets out of the harm’s way. A good understanding of the types of hazards and their risks that Ghana as a country face, as well as the characteristics of hazards that local governments, communities, and individuals must plan and prepare for, are essential components to enhance DRR. In this regard, UNDP supported NADMO to develop, print and disseminate over 4000 hard copies and soft copies of flood and drought risks, hazards and vulnerability maps across the country. The information generated from these efforts are stored in a form that can be readily used for anticipating and responding to natural hazards. 3. Besides these eff

The initiative forms part of efforts by the project to reduce the risks associated with disasters, especially in flood-prone areas. 2. As part of UNDP’s efforts to increase the adaptive capacity of rural communities to climate change impacts, while supporting the Government of Ghana to achieve Goal 6 of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) - Access to clean water and sanitation - the CREW project supported the drilling of 22 operational boreholes in 22 communities in the Bawku West and Bunkpurugu-Yunyoo Districts of the Upper East and Northern regions respectively. These boreholes are providing access to clean water to over 10,000 beneficiaries, mainly women and children. 3. 1. Climate Change Education program conducted in Junior High Schools and communities 2. CREMA developed and integrated within other activities using the “landscape approach” 3. Community spraying gangs supported to commercialize their operation in the Asunafo pilot landscape 4. Environmental sustainability and agricultural best practices mainstreamed into Cocoa Health Extension Division (CHED) under COCOBOD and the work of other Cocoa Life partners by developing training modules and training Community Extension Agents (CEAs) 5. The project is continuing with its Climate Change Education program in Junior High Schools (JHS) and Communities in the Asunafo Pilot Landscape. In 2015, science teachers from 17 schools were trained on Climate Change and Environmental Sustainability, and 12 schools established model school cocoa farms. The development of a CREMA in the Asunafo Pilot landscape covering 36 communities has reached an advanced stage, with the formation of the CREMA Executive Committee and preparation of the CREMA constitution and the bye-law pending the District Assembly approval.
As part of the capacity building program, the project organized an orientation/technical training workshop on the forest laws and community rights for forest management for 12 Cocoa Health Extension Division (CHED) District Extension Coordinators (DEC) and 240 Community Extension Agents (CEAs). At the same time, farmer sensitization and education campaign was conducted in seven Cocoa Life districts to create awareness on farmers’ rights and responsibilities under the law. Training materials comprising a trainers’ manual, posters and a brochure developed last year were widely disseminated. The project also promoted planting and registration of recommended economic trees by cocoa farmers to increase tree and carbon stocks on farms. In 2015, a total of 523,100 tree seedlings were distributed to farmers in 428 communities across seven districts.
The project has collaborated with CHED and Cocoa Research Institute Ghana (CRIG) to revise the environmental content of the current Extension Training Manual for the use in the training of extension agents. The developed manual focuses on sustainable cocoa production practices and serves as a supplementary resource material to the existing cocoa extension manual approved by CHED.

1) Hold Community level dialogues with farmers, landowners and Chiefs to discuss land tenure arrangements their effective on the adoption of environmental sustainable practices in the Asunafo Pilot Landscape and the Wassa East District 2) Launch a Climate Change Education campaign to educate and create awareness among Junior High Schools students and Communities in the Asunafo pilot landscape. 3) Complete the development of Asunafo CREMA through final devolution certification 4) Print copies of ESP's sustainability supplementary manual and use it to train CHED technical staff/CEAs on selected good agriculture and sustainable production practices. 5) Facilitate the registration of all project supported economic trees planted to date with the Forestry Commission (FC).

1)Two dialogues were organized for farmers, land owners and traditional authorities in the Asunafo North Municipal Assembly and the Wassa East districts to discuss strategies and procedures to improve the current land tenure arrangements and to explore incentives for the adoption of environmentally sustainable production practices. A total of 550 participants from 82 communities participated in the dialogue sessions organized at 4 venues in the 2 Districts. The sessions enabled participants, especially land owners and chiefs to better appreciate the relationship between land tenure and the refusal of farmers to adopt long term practices such as tree planting. Both land owners and the tenant farmers agreed at the meeting to cooperate with one another to develop benefit sharing mechanisms from adopting ESP practices on farms.
2)Five events were held including a workshop for 14 school teachers serving as patrons of the Environmental Clubs, to discuss progress of work and challenges facing the clubs and also to plan activities for 2016. As a result of this initiative, the capacities of science teachers from the participating schools were enhanced in introductory climate change science and the impacts of climate change. The teachers are mainstreaming this knowledge into their classroom in their respective schools. An inter-schools quiz competition was organized for Environmental Clubs from 16 JHS in the Asunafo Municipality with Kumaho M/A JHS emerging as overall winners followed by Fawohoyeden M/A (B) while Ampenkrom M/A JHS came third. The competition was to assess and measure students understanding and knowledge of climate change and also helped to deepen their interest in the campaign. The high scores recorded by contestants and high turn outs at the various quiz venues attested to the high level of student understanding. Monthly visits were made to all the participating schools throughout the reporting period to technically backstop them in carrying out their p

1) Technical standards for improved cookstoves gazetted 2) Testing and certification center at TCC fully operational by December 2015 3) Stakeholders educated on the cookstoves standards developed and the benfits of using improved cookstoves over traditional ones. 4) Zero used refrigerators entering Ghana market 5) 15,000 refrigerators exchanged through the rebate scheme

1, 2 and 3) The standards for improved cookstoves have been drafted by the mirror committee led by Ghana Standards Authority. This is done in parallel with the development of global ISO standards, which is receiving significant contributions from the Ghana Energy Commission. Comments have been received on the draft, however, it has been suggested to hold additional stakeholder consultations (in 2016) in order to receive as many inputs as possible, in particular from those stakeholders (like the manufacturers) who are going to be impacted the most by the enforcement of national standards. The Cookstove Testing and Expertise Laboratory was successfully established at the Technology Consulting Centre (TCC) of the Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology (KNUST) and commissioned in March 2015, and is fully functional. The laboratory is meant not only to test cookstoves (especially to verify compliance with the standards, when published), but also to conduct research to further improve the technology. The management and business processes of the lab are being streamlined to ensure business sustainability. In order to promote awareness on improved cookstoves, radio jingles were developed in 6 different languages, and aired on 45 local and national radio stations. The maiden Renewable Energy Fair was successfully organized by the Energy Commission alongside the West African Clean Environment and Energy Conference. It constituted a platform to discuss the renewable energy sector (policies, challenges, success stories etc.) and to showcase public and private interventions in the sector.
4 and 5) UNDP supported some exit strategies for the Refrigerator Energy Efficiency Project, which ended in 2014. In particular, support was provided to do conduct quarterly compliance monitoring activities to cover all the regions. The main objectives were to check the labels fixed on the refrigerators in the various retail and outlet shops for compliance with the labelling guide

1. Hold additional consultations to solicit views for the finalization of the Draft standards for improved cook stoves 2. Develop at least two bankable proposals for funding 3. Organize at least two awareness raising workshops on Productive Uses of Energy among MMDAs, Private Energy Service Providers, Financial Institutions and NGOs

1) The standards for improved cookstoves were drafted in 2015. Upon multi-stakeholder advice, it was agreed to hold additional consultations especially with manufacturers (the group who will be mainly affected by the standards) to get their inputs. Additionally, sampled household and institutional cookstoves from the market were tested to get further information on the standards and determine benchmarks. The Ghana Standards Authority will now convene the last meeting of the mirror committee to finalize the standards. Unfortunately, this could not take place in 2016. The Cookstove Testing and Expertise Laboratory established at the Technology Consulting Centre (TCC) of the Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology (KNUST) in 2015, was further equipped with a plasma cutter to improve research on cookstoves. 2) A Project Advisor (Finance) was recruited in 2015 to support the development of bankable projects to implement the SE4All Action Plan. In 2016, with the help of the advisor, the Energy Commission: submitted a proposal to scale-up irrigation scheme among smallholder farmers submitted to IFAD; submitted one Expression of interest proposal on Market based approaches on the diffusion of Clean Cooking Solutions to the African Development Bank (AfDB); submitted two project proposals to the National Designated Authority for the Green Climate Fund (GCF) and others. 3) 2 separate workshops have been held at the Energy Commission to create the needed awareness on Productive Uses of Energy among MMDAs, Private Energy Service Providers, Financial Institutions and NGOs. Guideline for catalogue has been developed and shared with stakeholders for their input. UNDP also supported the second edition of the Ghana Renewable Energy Fair, which a constituted a platform to discuss the renewable energy sector (policies, challenges, success stories etc.) and to showcase public and private interventions in the sector.The Energy Commission continued its awareness creation cam

1) 3 bankable projects fully developed with 2 securing funding for implementation. 2) Database of information on SEforALL interventions established at the Energy Commission 3) 150 stakeholders reached by PUE awareness creation activities and 3500 participated in RE Fair

The project will facilitate exchange of renewable energy expertise and technology between China and Ghana, building on China’s unique development experience.
capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: Broker learning, knowledge sharing and renewable energy transfer experience amongst Ghana, Zambia and China

description.narrative: Energy - power generation

1) Number of consultative meetings on RE policy and gaps in Ghana held. 2) Report on barriers for RET transfer produced 3) Report on criteria and specifications for selection of 4 RETs 4) number and type of training packages developed 5) number of reports and surveys developed and published; 6) Roadmap launched and disseminated; 7) Documents establishing PMUs and PSCs exist

comment.narrative: 1) Ghana adopted the Renewable Energy Act in 2011, but there is no master plan to implement it. 2) Barriers to effective transfer of Renewable Energy existed. 3) Currently, there is no demonstration site set up for Renewable Energy Technology Transfer (RETT) 4) There is no mechanism for up-scaling of RETs for Public-Private actors established, and capacity building required 5) The UNDP South-South Cooperation Framework 6) There is no existing mechanism for promoting Renewable Energy Technology Transfe 7) PMUs and PSCs haven’t been established.

1) Review of Chinese and Ghanaian Renewable Energy Policies conducted. 2) Report on barriers completed 3) Renewable Energy Master Plan developed 4) Stakeholder list developed; Project organization established; regular meetings held

1) A review of Ghanaian policies on renewable energy was conducted to identify gaps to address and opportunities to take in order to boost the sector and achieve the policy target of 10% of renewable energy (excluding large hydro) in the electricity generation mix by 2020. The review made concrete recommendations that will officially be presented to the Ministry of Power. These were also based on the experience from China, whose plans, regulations, strategies and incentives have made the country one of the largest producers of renewable energy. This review was conducted in a consultative manner (2 stakeholder workshops with 96 participants; 4 focus group discussions with specific stakeholder groups).
2) A study was conducted to identify barriers to renewable energy technology transfer RETT) to Ghana, and a road map developed to remove them. This was done by engaging several stakeholders at different levels. The study reviewed current technology transfer regulations; provided history of RETT in Ghana; identified specific political, economic/financial, market, institutional, awareness/information, technical, human skills, legal/regulatory, socio-cultural, and network barriers to RETT; detailed road map to address these challenges.
3) The main output for 2015 was the development of the Renewable Energy Master Plan. However, this was put on hold until 2016, as there was the need to complete other studies (like the policy review and barrier analysis mentioned above) and other government strategies (like the Strategic National Energy Plan) in order to fully understand the scope and content of the Master Plan. Preliminary activities have started, such as the development of a baseline for the Plan.
4) The Energy Commission initiated partnerships with Ghanaian research institutions to get technical support throughout project implementation, especially for the demonstration sites that will be created. These institutions will be paired with Chinese research institutions, i

1) Draft and submit to Parliament the Renewable Energy Master Plan (REMP) 2) Selection and adaptation of appropriate renewable energy technologies to be transferred 3) Facilities to receive, test, demonstrate and exhibit equipment and publish performance results 4) Set up Project Steering Committees

1) Draft and submit to Parliament the Renewable Energy Master Plan (REMP): A task force was constituted in 2015 with key members from the Ministry of Power, National Development and Planning Commission, Energy Commission and the Energy Centre of the Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology. The task force held 9 meetings to develop the first draft of the REMP by conducting extensive desk and field studies of past and on-going renewable energy initiatives and projects to identify success factors and implementation gaps or failures and how gaps identified could be addressed to ensure sustainability of interventions. However, the draft is almost completed with still some work to be done to finalize. The draft REMP also received some initial reviews and feed back from ACCA21 and researchers in China in key areas such as implementation actions and identifying key roles and defined, identify which ministries or agencies will do what and the roles and responsibilities clearly stated against each action plan. Also identifying priority actions/demonstration projects with clear financing provisions. It is now expected to be completed by January 2017 and then subjected to a series of multi-stakeholder reviews and submitted to Parliament mid-2017.
2) Selection and adaptation of appropriate renewable energy technologies to be transferred: The criteria for selection of the technologies was completed and the following technologies including wind and solar for irrigation, mini hydro for power generation, biogas and improved cook stoves for identified for implementation in the demonstration project phase to be carried out in 2017.
3) Facilities to receive, test, demonstrate and exhibit equipment and publish performance results: MOUs were signed between the IP and 5 research institutions under the project to develop guidelines and criteria for the selection of RETs for demonstration and to conduct pre-feasibility assessments across Ghana to select locations for them ada

1) Launch and disseminate the Ghana Renewable Energy Master Plan (REMP) 2) Barriers to effective transfer of Renewable Energy Technologies removed 3) Appropriateness of selected technologies (biogas, improved cook stoves, solar and wind power, and mini hydro) for transfer demonstrated 4) Increased use of Renewable Energy Technologies in Ghana supported through capacity building and financing mechanisms 5) Knowledge base and China – Ghana networks for South-South Cooperation on technology transfers 6) Mechanisms for up-scaling Renewable Energy Technology Transfer from China to Ghana established 7) Project management structures established and implementation supported

Consensus on issues of common concern among five major political parties has been built through an Inter-Party Platform established with support from UNDP as part of its Joint Party Support and Strengthening (J-PASS) project. Knowledge of 10 representatives (50% female) were improved to understand their commitment in enhancing women’s participation in political parties through their participation in an African High Level Dialogue on Democracy, Governance and Human Rights held in Kigali, Rwanda. Three studies on documenting best practices for the development of gender policies, membership data base and inter party communication policies for political parties have been commissioned with the draft reports ready for validation.

description.narrative: To support the Government of Ghana in strengthening their national capacities to effectively and efficiently plan for, access, manage, deploy and monitor climate financing in particular through the GCF once it is fully operational

- Number of national entities identified and assessed for National Implementing Entities (NIE) potential - Number of workshops held to strengthen climate change coordination - Reconstitution of the NCCC - Number of tools developed for economic and budget analysis of climate finance - Number of online knowledge management platforms to support project pipelines - Number of workshops to train stakeholders on prioritising procedures - Number of tools developed to assess and design climate interventions - Number of MRV templates developed

comment.narrative: - Ghanaian public and private entities not assessed for existing fiduciary governance capacity - No workshops held to strengthen coordination - National Climate Change Committee is not currently active - No tools developed for climate finance related economic and budget analysis - No online knowledge management platform to support project pipelines - No trainings for stakeholders on prioritising interventions - No tools developed to assess and design climate interventions - No MRV templates or guidance

1. Mapping and assessment of Ghanaian national public or private entities that are eligible to access funds from the GCF complete 2. Ghana’s climate change coordination across national and sub-national levels strengthened 3. Strengthening of climate change regulations, policies, plans and budgeting supported 4. Stakeholder access to information and knowledge products on climate change increased 5. Guidelines and procedures developed for prioritizing climate change needs and interventions 6. Market based and value chain business model tools developed to assess, design and measure climate change interventions, including Cost-Benefit Analysis (CBA) and project checklists and safeguards 7. Monitoring and evaluation (MRV) templates and guidance developed

The GCF readiness programme started implementation from June 2015 with the inception workshop, as the fund was only received to the country office in May. Following the inception, a half-day workshop was organized in August with the support from the GCF secretariat to increase stakeholder’s knowledge on the National Implementing Entities (NIEs) accreditation requirement and process. In November, National Designated Authority (NDA) for GCF, Real Sector Division of Ministry of Finance, advertised a call for application to identify potential NIEs candidates in Ghana. Capacity assessment of the identified entities will be conducted as a next step.
In order to strengthen climate change coordination, the project supported Ministry of Environment, Science, Technology, and Innovation (MESTI) to organize the National Climate Change Steering Committee. The committee reviewed Ghana’s progress in the preparation of Intended Nationally Determined Contributions to UNFCCC, and discussed the formation of working groups under the committee including climate finance working group.
The consultants were engaged to 1) develop the operational manual for NDA and 2) develop the climate change project prioritization tool. The prioritization tool will be used by national stakeholders to identify and prioritize the areas for GCF proposal development. Further, building up from the outcome of the Climate Public Expenditure and Institutional Review conducted by Ministry of Finance earlier this year, the project will support the development of the climate change budget and finance tracking tool.

1. Identify at least one potential entities as part efforts to Strengthen institutional and fiduciary capacity of Ghana to enable entity to access the GCF. 2. Support Ministry of Finance, The NDA to participate in at least one international climate change 3. One economic analysis tool and one budget analysis tool developed for climate finance planning in Ghana 4. Initiate the development of one knowledge platform or web based system to support Climate Change project pipelines 5. Ensure that Guidelines/manuals and procedures for prioritizing climate change needs and interventions in Ghana are developed. 6. Initiate the development of one CBA tool, one checklist, one safeguards tool developed for use in designing interventions 7. Initiate development of MRV systems and templates for use in 2 mitigation sectors, 3 adaptation sectors and 1 REDD+

1. Two potential National Implementing Entities (NIEs), Ecobank and Social Investment Fund have been identified for GCF accreditation. Ecobank Ghana Limited have started the accreditation process. 2. The Ministry of Finance (The NDA) has been supported to attend GCF event in Songdo, South Korea in April 2016. Additional support is being given to the NDA to attend the COP 22 and to participate in the GCF Readiness side event at Marrakesh. 3. Climate Change finance tracking tools have been developed. The Climate Change Finance Tools are intended to help implement the national architecture for climate change finance in Ghana. This architecture was considered in Ghana’s First Biennial Update Report to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) in 2015. 4. The Climate Data hub, originally designed by Environmental Protection Agency with support from UNDP is being upgraded to support pipeline projects and provide additional information and policies relating to climate change. 5. A prioritization tool providing guidelines for initial evaluation of a range of climate change adaptation and mitigation options has been developed. A prioritization workshop to test the tool and select pipeline projects was also organized for selected institutions. The project prioritization tool is designed to provide the guideline for National Designated Authority (NDA) and Technical Advisory Committee (TAC) to prioritize climate change project proposal portfolios for submission to GCF, for funding and engagement with Development Partners, other dedicated climate funds and private sector for financing. The tool has been used to select or prioritize a number of adaptation and mitigation actions aimed at preparing a full proposal for submission to GCF. 6. The Process for the development of a CBA tool has been initiated by collaborating with the NAP -Global Support Programme to provide training for Key government staff (National Development Planning Commission, Ministry of E

1. Complete accreditation of at least one potential entities as part efforts to strengthen institutional and fiduciary capacity of Ghana to enable entity to access the Green Climate Fund. 2. Support Ministry of Finance, the National Designated Authority (NDA) to the GCF, to participate in at least one international climate change 3. Complete the upgrade of one knowledge platform or web based system to support Climate Change project pipelines 4. Complete development of relevant and robust MRV frameworks, templates, and guidance for climate finance 5. Support at least two meetings of the National Climate Change Steering Committee (NCCSC) to enhance climate change coordination 6. Support at least 2 meetings of the Technical Advisory Committee of the NDA 7. Initiate the integration of Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) into national development plans

MID YEAR UPDATES 1. Ecobank is in the process of completing the first stage (Completeness check) of the GCF accreditation process. Social Investment Fund has received a nomination letter from the NDA to start the accreditation process. It is expected that SIF will start the accreditation process in July 2017. 2. The Climate Data hub, originally designed by Environmental Protection Agency with support from UNDP has been upgraded to support pipeline projects and provide additional information and policies relating to climate change and the NDCs. This was completed in March 2017 3. MRV system on climate finance was completed in April 2017 and it is expected to be implemented in parallel with the climate finance tracking 4. The first meeting of the NCCSC was supported in May 2017 and a subsequent one is expected to be held in August/ September 2017 5. The first meeting of the NDA’s Technical Advisory Committee was held in June 2017 to support the decision making on GCF project pipeline. A second meeting has been scheduled for August 2017 6. The development of a checklist to support the integration of NDCs in development plans commenced in June 2017 and a pilot dissemination is expected to be completed by September 2017

title.narrative: GFDRR Draft Project Document 8th draft to WB 4feb14
GFDRR Project Proposal 8th draft to WB 4feb14

description.narrative: Advocacy and capacity building for disaster risk reduction and preparedness in Ghana
capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: Conduct Training on the 10 DRR Modules for 80 participants selected across the country. Carry out advocacy and sensitization workshops and conduct one simulation exercise

description.narrative: 1) Report covering the celebration of the International Day for DRR 2) Minutes and approved programme for the annual review meeting of the national platform 3) Draft and final awareness creation materials submitted 4) Core Training Agenda developed 5) Report on regional and district simulation exercises organised.

comment.narrative: 1) The is annual event, and has been celebrated in previous year including 2014 2) National platform already exist 3) There are existing materials but need to be updated 4) There is existing literature and different training programmes with various academic and learning institutions 5) Similar prepared and awareness stimulation exercise are in place

1) Organize high level, public events, in particular within the context of the International Day for DRR, to raise awareness on specific topics and issues related to DRR in Ghana. 2) Support awareness and advocacy activities organized by the National Platform for DRR 3) Develop awareness creation material for disaster risk reduction and prevention. 4) Develop a core training agenda addressing disaster risk reduction and management for government cadres from various administrative levels. 5) Organize 1 regional and 1 district simulation exercises to strengthen disaster preparedness.

1) Two main events were organized to sensitize on Disaster Risk Reduction (DRR). The International Day for Disaster Reduction was celebrated in a disaster prone community called Anyamam, with focus on the importance of indigenous and traditional knowledge. In addition, radio discussions were held and a social media campaign was carried out around this theme. The second event is the annual meeting of the National Platform on DRR, which brought together the main stakeholders involved in disaster management. It was an opportunity to take stock of 2015 activities on DRR both at the regional and national levels, and to strategize on 2016 advocacy activities in line with the new Sendai Framework for Action.
4) A stock-tacking exercise was conducted to map out existing DRR programmes or trainings in tertiary institutions and identify gaps. On the basis of this, a core training agenda addressing disaster risk reduction and management for government cadres from various administrative levels was developed and validated by stakeholders from tertiary education institutions. The actual programs will be developed and carried out in 2016.
5) A regional simulation exercise was organized in the Upper West Region, using floods as disaster scenario. The aim was to assess the preparedness and response capability of major stakeholders in disaster risk management, test effectiveness of the existing contingency plans, and evaluate the co-ordination level among these stakeholders. About 230 participants from national, regional, and district level institutions participated. A debriefing session with 70 participants was held to discuss main issues and recommendations.

1) Organize two high level, public events, involving international, national and local stakeholders to raise awareness on DRR specific topics and issues in Ghana. 2) Support two awareness and advocacy activities organized by the National Platform for DRR. 3) Develop awareness creation materials for Disaster Risk Reduction and Prevention. 4) Develop training manual/material for adult education on DRR. 5) Pilot test four training sessions on DRR using the manual/material developed. 6) Organize one National, two Regional and three District Simulation exercises.

1) Two high level advocacy events were organized to educate and to raise awareness on specific issues relating to DRR. Multi-stakeholder Making Cities Resilient meeting was organized to sensitize on the to raise more awareness on the social and economic impacts of common disaster events on vulnerable groups and locations in the city of Accra and the wider Greater Accra Metropolitan Area (GAMA), as well as highlight the critical link between governance and urban vulnerability/resilience for increased commitment of city authorities. Urban resilience conference with local authorities was also organized and it created the opportunity to discuss ways of achieving mainstreaming of disaster risk reduction in local development through inclusive planning and effective coordination. Participants were from MDAs, MMDAs, academia and UN Agencies. The outputs (communique) from these two events will be integrated into one advocacy tool for further action to improve urban resilience. 2) NADMO (the main partner) in consultation with World Bank (the donor) advised to sponsor the IDDR2016 celebration and also support the Ghana Institute of Planner's (GIP) Annual Review Meeting due to essence of the themes and aims of these activities to the project goal. The IDDR2016 focused on the implementation of the Sendai Framework for DRR (Output 1). This event created an avenue for local participants to learn from other ECOWAS countries' experiences and also put in strategies for local implementation. The GIP Annual Review meeting, with the aim of building resilient environment through local planning, brought together stakeholders to re-affirm the role of Planners in achieving the SDGs. 3) Fire Safety and Flood awareness materials have been developed for printing and dissemination by end of year. These materials are to enhance awareness on DRR related issues; specifically on floods and fire outbreaks in the urban settings. 4) DRR manual involving 10 modules have been developed by University of
Project activities were completed in 2016. 2017 will be used only for final project reporting and minor follow-up activities.

comment.narrative:
The Ebola Virus Disease (EVD) outbreak was first reported to WHO in March 2014. As at 29 October 2014, about 14,000 cases and nearly 5,000 deaths have been recorded mainly from the three most affected countries, Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone.
Ghana is considered as being at high risk of importation of EVD in view of a combination of varied number of factors which have the potential to trigger an outbreak which will have a devastating impact on health, economic, social, security and overall development of the country. Some of these factors include

Though no Ebola case has been registered in Ghana, the UN system under and the UN Coordination framework continuous to coordinate and liaise with development partners and government to keep the country in readiness and out of risk.

1. Undertake an evaluation of UN JP on EVD 2. Conducted risk assessments of virus spill over from wildlife/animals to humans 3. Publish documents developed by Agencies on surveillance, sensitization etc. on EVD

Evaluation conducted and final report available (title: Review of Public Health Emergency Response, Preparedness and Resources in Ghana; Achievements, Challenges and Directions; 2016
Assessments and surveys undertaken and findings documented as: Capacity Assessment of Wildlife/Animal Surveillance System and Protocol for Wild Life Surveillance
The following 5 documents were published to be distributed to health institutions and other stakeholders: • EVD WORKPLACE ACTION CHECKLIST • FINAL KAP STUDY REPORT REV,05112015 • GHANA / REGIONAL EVD PREPAREDNESS CHECKLIST • TRAINING BOOKLET ON EVD-­‐03-­‐NOV-­‐2014 • WHO EVD POCKET GUIDE FOR WEB
